results.snippet: It is a challenge marketing people hope they never have to face - restoring the image of a product linked in the public mind with death.   But that is the sizable - and some say hopeless - task that now confronts the marketing team for Tylenol, the...
results.lead_paragraph: It is a challenge marketing people hope they never have to face - restoring the image of a product linked in the public mind with death. But that is the sizable - and some say hopeless - task that now confronts the marketing team for Tylenol, the nonprescription drug that was the nation's biggest-selling over-the-counter pain reliever. Indeed, Tylenol's past marketing efforts have been so successful that it commanded a market share estimated at 37 percent. But now, of course, the drug's image has been devastated by the tracing of seven deaths to cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules. The deaths touched off a nationwide recall of capsule forms of the drug by its manufacturer, McNeil Consumer Products, a division of Johnson & Johnson.

headline.main: WERNER HERZOG'S STRUGGLE FOR MIND OVER MATTER

results.snippet: ''HOW pure is the diamond that has come out of all this dirt and mud?'' Werner Herzog asked rhetorically about ''Fitzcarraldo,'' the film that closed this year's New York Film Festival to critical acclaim and that opened yesterday at the Paris...
results.lead_paragraph: ''HOW pure is the diamond that has come out of all this dirt and mud?'' Werner Herzog asked rhetorically about ''Fitzcarraldo,'' the film that closed this year's New York Film Festival to critical acclaim and that opened yesterday at the Paris Theater. One thing is certain - the ''dirt and mud'' is in this case memorable in its own right. Even for a director of extraordinary persistence, which Mr. Herzog has shown in the making of ''Aguirre, the Wrath of God,'' ''The Mystery of Kaspar Hauser'' and other films, ''Fitzcarraldo'' represents a victory of mind over some enormously unwieldy matter. ''I would have done 'Fitzcarraldo' in Central Park if I had had jungle there, and a mountain high enough, and two rivers,'' insisted the 40-year-old German director in a recent interview. ''I would have loved to direct it from a suite on Central Park South.'' Nonetheless, he journeyed to two remote sites along the Amazon, endured delays and the loss of his stars Jason Robards and Mick Jagger, and finally spent four and a half years and $6 million to see his dream realized.

results.snippet: To the Editor:    Do away with Halloween? Why would Theodore Black (''Treat Halloween as a Trick,'' Op-Ed Oct. 9) want to stop there? Why not go ahead and banish Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny and the Tooth Fairy? I wonder what experiences Mr. Black...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Do away with Halloween? Why would Theodore Black (''Treat Halloween as a Trick,'' Op-Ed Oct. 9) want to stop there? Why not go ahead and banish Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny and the Tooth Fairy? I wonder what experiences Mr. Black has had on Halloween all these years. As a mother of two girls, ages 3 and 6, and as a resident of Manhattan all my life, I have not had any of the violent experiences to which he refers.

headline.main: MILITARY'S FUTURE IN SPACE: A MATTER OF WAR OR PEACE

results.snippet: The seemingly inexorable push toward expanded military operations in space has raised some of the most complex and difficult questions ever faced by the world's political and military leaders. Is this course truly inevitable, given the nature of...
results.lead_paragraph: The seemingly inexorable push toward expanded military operations in space has raised some of the most complex and difficult questions ever faced by the world's political and military leaders. Is this course truly inevitable, given the nature of man and international rivalries? Will it reduce the risk of war or merely lead to another, more costly phase of the arms race and turn man's newest frontier into a potential battleground? Many military planners and their political allies, reciting maxims of seapower, airpower and the foot soldier's ''high ground,'' tend to take for granted the strategic value of space and its ultimate exploitation by the superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union. They believe that the widespread militarization of space cannot be avoided and advocate the development of new weapons and defenses that, if deployed, would fulfill their prophecy. History, they contend, is in their camp. Ronald H. Stivers, Assistant Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for policy, said recently: ''History teaches us that each time a new medium is opened to man it is exploited to gain a military advantage. The course of world affairs has repeatedly been altered by the nation which first grasped the advantages offered by developing the military potential of the newest medium.''

headline.main: SCHMITT, ASTRONAUT NOW IN SENATE, STRUGGLES TO HOLD NEW MEXICO SEAT

results.snippet: E.T., phone home. Jack Schmitt needs help.  As an astronaut, Harrison Schmitt flew to the moon in 1972, and that feat helped launch a political career that landed him in the Senate four years later. But this fall the re-election campaign of the New...

byline.original: By STEVEN V. ROBERTS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: E.T., phone home. Jack Schmitt needs help. As an astronaut, Harrison Schmitt flew to the moon in 1972, and that feat helped launch a political career that landed him in the Senate four years later. But this fall the re-election campaign of the New Mexico Republican seems to be in trouble. A poll released this week by Zia Research for KOAT-TV here showed that Attorney General Jeff Bingaman, the Democratic nominee, had moved to within 7 percentage points of Senator Schmitt and was gaining steadily.

results.snippet: For a long time, the common way to insult a politician was to call him a ''turkey.'' Republicans used to ridicule Jimmy Carter, for instance, by asking, ''Why does the President's staff always carry a frozen turkey on Air Force One?'' Answer:...
results.lead_paragraph: For a long time, the common way to insult a politician was to call him a ''turkey.'' Republicans used to ridicule Jimmy Carter, for instance, by asking, ''Why does the President's staff always carry a frozen turkey on Air Force One?'' Answer: ''spare parts.'' But then came a change in fashion. ''Wimp'' became the political pejorative of choice.

headline.main: FEAR OF TAINTED CANDY PROMPTS WIDE CONCERN FOR HALLOWEENERS

results.snippet: Halloween, with its tales of witches and goblins and ghouls, has always been a holiday that mixed fun and fear. But this year, as children are getting ready to put on garish makeup, plastic noses and ghostly sheets, there is more fear than usual.  ...

byline.original: By SUZANNE DALEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Halloween, with its tales of witches and goblins and ghouls, has always been a holiday that mixed fun and fear. But this year, as children are getting ready to put on garish makeup, plastic noses and ghostly sheets, there is more fear than usual. As the night approaches when children turn into their favorite fantasy characters and go from door to door collecting candy, often from strangers, the recent incidents of cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules and dozens of other copycat poisonings are causing increased concern. Across the country, parents and community leaders are trying to come up with ways to keep every Wonder Woman, astronaut and fairy princess safe tomorrow night.
